awd_titl_txt: Puzzles, Quantum K-Theory, and Other Topics in Schubert Calculus
awd_abstract_narration:
This research project concerns several open questions in the general area of enumerative geometry. The motivating goal in this subject is to determine the number of geometric figures of a fixed type that satisfy a list of conditions. These conditions could involve that the figures contain given points, meet other figures, or have tangents with specified properties. Surprisingly, while it can be extremely difficult to determine the precise list of solution figures that satisfy the conditions, it is often possible to predict the number of such solutions.  The search for formulas for the number of solutions to enumerative problems has uncovered deep and beautiful combinatorial structures that are of interest in numerous fields, including geometry, combinatorics, representation theory, complexity theory in computer science, and mirror symmetry in physics. The PI will engage both graduate and undergraduate students in his research with the aim of recruiting new talent to mathematics in general and to enumerative geometry in particular.  The PI is currently the thesis advisor of one Ph.D student, and two additional students have recently completed their Ph.D degrees under his supervision. The PI has supervised projects in the Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) program at Rutgers University in 7 out of the past 8 summers.  The awarded research grant will enable him to continue this activity. The PI will also develop computer software to facilitate research in his area, and he will help organizing conferences and workshops.

Much information about the enumerative geometry of subvarieties in a flag manifold is encoded in its cohomology ring, as well as in more general cohomology theories.  A major goal in Schubert calculus is to obtain formulas for the multiplicative structure constants of this ring with respect to its basis of Schubert classes.  The PI will attempt to prove a positive combinatorial formula that expresses the cohomological structure constants of any three-step flag variety as the number of puzzles that can be created using a list of puzzle pieces. The Gromov-Witten invariants of a flag manifold X count the number of rational curves that meet general Schubert varieties in X when this number is finite.  When infinitely many curves meet a general configuration of Schubert varieties, the collection of these curves form a moduli space called a Gromov-Witten variety. Gromov-Witten varieties in turn define K-theoretic Gromov-Witten invariants that are encoded in the quantum K-theory ring of X.  The study of this ring provides a useful benchmark for our understanding of the singularities and rationality properties of Gromov-Witten varieties and related spaces.  The PI will attempt to answer several open questions about positivity and finiteness properties of quantum K-theory.  The methods to be used in this project come from geometry and combinatorics, with computer experiments as a central tool.

por.por_cntn:
The PI and his students and collaborators have studied the enumerative geometry and intersection theory of flag manifolds and their Schubert varieties, including the geometry of families of parametrized curves that meet Schubert varieties in general position.  He has written five research articles in this area, and has given invited talks and lecture series about his research at several events spanning France, China, Switzerland, Denmark, Canada, and USA. The PI has also supervised both graduate and undergraduate students in research projects, and he has developed computer software to facilitate research in his area of expertise.

When finitely many curves are incident to Schubert varieties in a flag manifold, the number of curves is known as a Gromov-Witten invariant, and is encoded as a structure constant in the (small) quantum cohomology ring of the flag manifold. The PI's research indicates that this ring is in many cases determined by properties that are clear from its construction, such as its associativity, grading, and the positivity of its defining Gromov-Witten invariants.  This has been proved for Grassmannians up to a scaling factor that is determined by Witten's presentation.

The more general quantum K-theory ring encodes geometric information about infinite families of curves incident to Schubert varieties.  The PI's research has led to simple formulas that make it possible to carry out computations in the quantum K-theory ring of any cominuscule flag variety. It has also been established that there is a unique smallest possible degree of a parametrized curve connecting two opposite Schubert varieties in any flag manifold.  This minimal degree plays the role of a multi-parameter distance between the Schubert varieties, and is related to the product of the Schubert varieties in the quantum K-theory ring.

The PI has supervised six undergraduate students in Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) projects as Rutgers University during the grant period. One of these projects resulted in a proof of a conjecture of the PI and Mihalcea, now published by his REU students in the journal Transformation Groups.   The PI has also coordinated the mathematics part of the REU program at Rutgers during the last 3 years.  One graduate student completed his Ph.D. under the PI's supervision, and continued to a postdoc position at Ohio State University.

The PI has coorganized three research conferences at Rutgers University, including a 4-day conference on K-theory, Cyclic Homology and Motives, an AMS Special Session on Modern Schubert Calculus, and an Algebraic Geometry Northeastern Series (AGNES) meeting.  Finally, he has served as chair of the organizing committee for a semester program in Combinatorial Algebraic Geometry, scheduled to run in the Spring of 2021 at the Institute for Computational and Experimental Research in Mathematics (ICERM) at Brown University.
